abstract.introduction: Briefly introduces driving fatigue, EEG for detection, and challenges.
abstract.advancements: Summarizes machine learning advancements addressing these challenges, especially deep learning and hybrid approaches.
contributions: Analysis of trends in ML for EEG-based fatigue detection
Techniques for addressing core issues like subject variability and channel reduction
Identification of future research directions for practical deployment

subsections.title: Background
example: Defines driver fatigue and its impact on road safety.
Emphasizes need for real-time fatigue detection systems.
Introduces EEG as a promising physiological signal for fatigue monitoring.

subsections.title: Core Challenges in EEG-Based Fatigue Detection

subsections.title: Subject Variability
subsections.example: Discusses the inherent differences in EEG signals between individuals.

subsections.title: Reduced Channel Count
subsections.example: Explains the need for practical systems with fewer electrodes.

subsections.title: Multiclass Sleepiness Classification
subsections.example: Emphasizes the importance of detecting different levels of fatigue beyond binary classification.

subsections.title: Robustness and Generalization
subsections.example: Addresses the need for models that perform well in real-world conditions and across diverse populations.

subsections.title: Explainability and Interpretability
subsections.example: Underscores the necessity of understanding model decisions for trust and adoption in safety-critical applications.

subsections.title: Real-world Application and Usability
subsections.example: Discusses the challenges of deploying EEG-based systems in practical, real-world driving scenarios.

subsections.title: Data Scarcity and Class Imbalance
subsections.example: Highlights the difficulties in obtaining large, balanced datasets for training robust models.

subsections.title: Motivation and Objectives
example: Highlight the need for a review that focuses on how research has addressed these core challenges.
State the objectives, emphasizing the analysis of machine learning trends and their impact on these challenges.

sections.title: Addressing Core Challenges with Machine Learning
sections.section_id: 2. Addressing Core Challenges with Machine Learning

subsections.title: Tackling Subject Variability
subsections.description: Methods to address subject variability in EEG based driving fatigue detection.

methods.title: Transfer Learning and Domain Adaptation
methods.description: Discuss domain adaptation techniques (e.g., Maximum Mean Discrepancy, adversarial methods) to align EEG distributions across subjects.

examples.description: Domain adaptation using LA-MSDA to improve cross-subject fatigue classification accuracy.
AMK-TMM leverages knowledge from multiple source subjects for cross-subject EEG analysis.
FLDANN for domain adaptation to address individual EEG variability.
Presents PASAN-CA, utilizing coordinate attention mechanisms and subdomain adaptation for cross-subject fatigue detection.
Proposes a cross-dataset adaptation framework to address the challenge of limited data in the target domain.
Utilizes Entropy Minimization (EM) for domain alignment to improve cross-dataset driver drowsiness recognition.
Introduces DTDDAN that incorporates domain adaptation and dynamic pseudo labeling for cross-subject fatigue recognition.
Proposes CS2DA method, which addresses domain shift for robust fatigue detection model.

methods.why_introduced: To leverage knowledge from multiple subjects and reduce the need for extensive data collection for each new user.To reduce the need for subject-specific calibration and improve model generalization across individuals.
methods.trend: Increasing use of transfer learning to leverage data from multiple subjects and reduce the need for extensive data collection for each new user.

methods.title: Personalized Models
methods.description: Discuss approaches for building personalized fatigue detection models.Explore techniques like adaptive learning and model fine-tuning.

examples.description: Presents an adaptive algorithm that adjusts to individual EEG differences, improving fatigue detection accuracy.
Utilizes a regression-based framework for continuous driving fatigue estimation, showing improved feasibility compared to traditional methods by adapting to individual physiological responses.
Employs an adaptive Hermite decomposition method with evolutionary algorithms for EEG feature extraction, enhancing drowsiness detection by adapting to individual EEG signal characteristics.

methods.why_introduced: To account for individual differences in EEG responses to fatigue. To improve model accuracy by tailoring predictions to individual users.To address subject variability and improve model performance by adapting to individual physiological responses.
methods.trend: Growing interest in tailoring models to individual users for improved accuracy.

methods.title: Feature Engineering for Invariant Representations
methods.description: Discuss feature extraction methods that are less sensitive to subject variability.

examples.description: Investigates inter-channel relationships for online prediction of microsleep states.
Employs sparse representation classification to address subject variability.

methods.why_introduced: To extract features that are more robust to individual differences in EEG signals

subsections.title: Reducing the Number of EEG Channels
subsections.section_id: 2.2 Reducing the Number of EEG Channels
subsections.description: Methods to reduce the number of EEG channels while maintaining detection accuracy.

methods.title: Channel Selection Algorithms
methods.description: Review algorithms for selecting the most informative EEG channels.Discuss techniques like filter methods, wrapper methods, and embedded methods.

Introduces a method (DK-MOEA) that balances channel selection with classification accuracy.

methods.title: Spatial Filtering Techniques
methods.description: Discuss techniques like Common Spatial Patterns (CSP) and its variants.

examples.description: Employs feature weighting to identify the importance of different EEG features, with a focus on crucial brain regions

methods.why_introduced: To enhance signal quality and reduce the number of electrodes needed for fatigue detection.
methods.trend: Using spatial filtering to improve signal quality and reduce the number of electrodes.

methods.title: Source Localization Techniques
methods.description: discuss source localization as a method to identify key brain regions for fatigue detection.

methods.trend: Potentially reducing the number of sensors by focusing on specific brain regions.

sections.section_id: 3. The Role of Deep Learning and Hybrid Models

subsections.title: Advantages of Deep Learning in EEG Analysis
subsections.section_id: 3.1 Advantages of Deep Learning in EEG Analysis

subsections.title: Automatic Feature Learning
subsections.description: Discuss the ability of deep learning models to automatically learn relevant features from raw EEG data.

example.description: Demonstrates a hybrid model leveraging raw EEG signals and deep learning for drowsiness detection.
Automates feature learning in a deep learning model for fatigue detection, providing better generalizability.
Introduces end-to-end deep learning for drowsiness recognition, eliminating manual feature selection.
Uses a CNN to predict drowsiness from EEG images, showcasing automatic feature learning.
Employs CNNs for automated EEG analysis in driver fatigue detection, avoiding manual feature extraction.

subsections.why_introduced: To reduce reliance on manual feature engineering and potentially discover novel fatigue-related features.

subsections.title: Handling Large Datasets
subsections.description: Discuss the suitability of deep learning for handling large and complex EEG datasets.

example.description: Utilizes a large dataset of 1187 driving sessions to train a sleepiness detection model.

subsections.why_introduced: To leverage the increasing availability of EEG data and improve model performance.

subsections.title: Capturing Complex Patterns
subsections.description: Analyze the ability of deep networks to capture nonlinear relationships and complex patterns in EEG signals.

example.description: Utilizes ACF-GCN to capture spatial-temporal-frequency relationships in EEG, enhancing fatigue level estimation.
Presents a multi-model fusion method for classifying EEG-based sleep stages, addressing under-detection of S1 and REM stages.
Uses a CNN to automate feature extraction from raw EEG, demonstrating high accuracy in drowsiness detection.
Integrates wavelets, ICA, and hierarchical clustering for automatic EEG artifact handling, improving fatigue classification.
Uses CNN for drowsiness detection from EEG, achieving high accuracy.

subsections.why_introduced: Why Introduced: To model the intricate dynamics of brain activity associated with fatigue.

subsections.title: Attention Mechanisms
subsections.description: Explain how attention mechanisms can highlight important features or time points in EEG signals.

subsections.trend: Providing insights into the model's decision-making process by highlighting influential features.

subsections.title: Visualization Techniques
subsections.description: Discuss methods for visualizing learned features and model activations (e.g., t-SNE, heatmaps).

subsections.description: Explore techniques for extracting human-interpretable rules from complex models.

subsections.trend: Translating model decisions into understandable rules that can be validated by domain experts.

subsections.title: Model-Agnostic Methods
subsections.description: Discuss methods like SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) and LIME (Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations) that can be applied to any machine learning model.

examples.description: Utilizes SHAP values to identify the most influential EEG features in fatigue detection.
Suggests future work could involve developing deeper model explanations, possibly hinting at the use of model-agnostic methods like SHAP or LIME for interpretability.

subsections.trend: Providing post-hoc explanations for model predictions without being tied to a specific model architecture.

methods.title: Rationale for Multimodal Fusion
methods.description: Discuss the limitations of relying solely on EEG for fatigue detection and the potential benefits of incorporating other physiological signals and behavioral measures. Highlight the potential benefits of incorporating other physiological signals (e.g., ECG, EOG, EMG) and behavioral measures (e.g., eye tracking, facial expressions, vehicle dynamics)

methods.trend: Growing interest in multimodal data fusion to provide a more comprehensive and robust assessment of driver fatigue.

subsections.title: Early Fusion (Feature-Level Fusion)
subsections.description: Discuss different approaches for combining multimodal data, such as early fusion (feature-level), late fusion (decision-level), and hybrid fusion.

examples.description: Combines statistical and deep learning features for EEG-based drowsiness detection (early fusion).
Utilizes feature-level fusion via CCA to combine EEG and eye-tracking data (early fusion).
Employs a multi-model fusion method, combining C-SVM and OC-SVM models for sleep stage classification (late fusion).
Utilizes a fusion-separation mechanism to combine EEG and ECG modalities, allowing independent utilization of features from both for enhanced accuracy (hybrid fusion).
Employs a feature fusion module (FFM) that integrates spatial and temporal features using channel attention mechanisms (hybrid fusion).
Utilizes a cross-modal predictive alignment module to enhance the fusion of features from EEG and eye tracking data (hybrid fusion).
Employs multimodal split-band fusion and a topology self-aware attention mechanism for integrating EEG and EOG features (hybrid fusion).

subsections.trend: Exploration of various fusion strategies to maximize the benefits of multimodal data integration.

subsections.title: Late Fusion (Decision-Level Fusion)
subsections.description: Analyze approaches that combine the outputs of separate classifiers trained on each modality.

examples.description: Uses a majority voting mechanism to combine outputs from multiple classifiers.
Employs a multi-model fusion method, combining C-SVM and OC-SVM models for sleep stage classification.
